{{other uses|Fort George (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox NRHP | name = Fort George | nrhp_type = | image = File:FORT GEORGE.jpg | caption = Fort George - British fort built to defend their colony of [[New Ireland (Maine)|New Ireland]] | location= Wadsworth St. off Battle Ave., [[Castine, Maine]] | lat_degrees = 44 | lat_minutes = 23 | lat_seconds = 27 | lat_direction = N | long_degrees = 68 | long_minutes = 48 | long_seconds = 20 | long_direction = W | locmapin = Maine#USA | built = {{Start date|1779}} | architect OR builder = | added = December 30, 1969 | area = {{convert|7|acre}} | governing_body = State | refnum = 69000007<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> }}
'''Fort George''' (also sometimes known as Fort Majabigwaduce, Castine, or Penobscot) was a palisaded [[Earthworks (engineering)#Military use|earthwork]] fort built in 1779 by [[Great Britain]] during the [[American Revolutionary War]] in [[Castine, Maine]]. Located at a high point on the Bagaduce Peninsula, the fort was built as part of an initiative by the British to establish a new colony called [[New Ireland (Maine)|New Ireland]]. It was the principal site of the British defense during the [[Massachusetts]]-organized [[Penobscot Expedition]], a disastrous attempt to retake Castine launched in response to the British move. The British re-occupied Castine in the [[War of 1812]] from September 1814 to April 1815, rebuilding Fort George and establishing smaller forts around it, again creating the New Ireland colony. The remains of the fort, now little more than its earthworks, are part of a state-owned and town-maintained park.
==Description and history== Fort George is today a roughly square earthwork, about {{convert|200|ft|m}} on each side, with [[bastion]]s at the corners that project out an additional {{convert|40|ft|m}}. These works are for the most part about {{convert|10|ft|m}} in height, although the easternmost bastion is {{convert|20|ft|m}} high. Features of the fort that have not survived include a [[palisade]], [[moat]], and gateway.<ref name=NRHP>{{cite web|url={{NRHP url|id=69000007}}|title=NRHP nomination for Fort George|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2015-02-12}}</ref> The fort is one of a series of defenses erected by the British in 1779, which notably included the digging of a canal across much of the neck separating the Bagaduce Peninsula from the rest of the mainland.
Castine is set at a strategically significant location near the head of [[Penobscot Bay]], and was a point of conflict at several times between the 17th and 19th centuries. Pursuant to plans for establishing a military presence on the coast of Maine as well as the colony of [[New Ireland (Maine)|New Ireland]], a British force led by General [[Francis McLean (British army officer)|Francis McLean]] arrived off Castine in June 1779, seized the town, and established Fort George and other fortifications in the area. The state of [[Massachusetts]], of which Maine was then a part, responded by raising a large militia force, which in an operation known as the [[Penobscot Expedition]], disastrously failed in its attempt to dislodge the British. The fort was not abandoned by the British until 1784, and was not re-used by the United States until after the War of 1812.<ref name=NRHP/><ref>{{cite book | last1 = Wade | first1 = Arthur P. | last2 = | first2 = | title = Artillerists and Engineers: The Beginnings of American Seacoast Fortifications, 1794-1815 | publisher = CDSG Press | year = 2011 | pages = 235-246 | isbn = 978-0-9748167-2-2}}</ref><ref>The absence of Fort George from the Secretary of War's reports for 1808 and 1811 indicates that it was not used by the Federal government. The "Fort Georges" in the 1811 report is [[Fort St. George (Thomaston, Maine)|Fort St. George]] in Thomaston.</ref>
The British re-occupied Castine in the War of 1812 from September 1814 to April 1815, again establishing New Ireland. They rebuilt Fort George, renamed the captured Fort Madison (aka Fort United States) as Fort Castine,<ref>[http://www.fortwiki.com/Fort_Madison_(1) Fort Madison aka Castine at FortWiki.com]</ref> and built Forts Furieuse,<ref>[http://www.fortwiki.com/Fort_Furieuse Fort Furieuse at FortWiki.com]</ref> Gosselin,<ref>[http://www.fortwiki.com/Fort_Gosselin Fort Gosselin at FortWiki.com]</ref> Griffith,<ref>[http://www.fortwiki.com/Fort_Griffith Fort Griffith at FortWiki.com]</ref> and Sherbrooke.<ref>[http://www.fortwiki.com/Fort_Sherbrooke_(2) Fort Sherbrooke at FortWiki.com]</ref><ref name=Roberts1>{{cite book | last = Roberts | first = Robert B. | authorlink = | title = Encyclopedia of Historic Forts: The Military, Pioneer, and Trading Posts of the United States | publisher = Macmillan | year = 1988 | pages = 363-364, 373-374 | location = New York | isbn = 0-02-926880-X }}</ref> They also refurbished the peninsula's canal defense line. They withdrew after the cessation of hostilities, and following a brief period of American use, the fort was abandoned and demolished in 1819.<ref>[http://www.northamericanforts.com/East/me.html#Castine Forts of Castine at NorthAmericanForts.com]</ref>
The state of Maine acquired the fort in 1940, and twenty years later provided funds to rebuild a magazine with other improvements.<ref name=Roberts1/> The site of the fort's remains is now a park of {{convert|7|acre|ha}}, owned by the state and maintained by the town.<ref name=plan>{{cite web|url=http://castine.me.us/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/Castine-Comp-Plan-Adopted-2010-11-02.pdf|title=Castine Comprehensive Plan, 2010|publisher=Town of Castine|accessdate=2015-02-12}}</ref> The site was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1969.<ref name="nris"/> Fort George is the site of Majabigwaduce, the location for Bernard Cornwell's 2010 book ''[[The Fort (novel)|The Fort]]'', which is about the Penobscot Expedition.
